sentence.content: U.S. prosecutors pressured Japan&apost;s wartime prime minister, Gen. Hideki Tojo, into changing testimony at his trial to avoid incriminating Emperor Hirohito in war crimes, a television documentary claims.

sentence.content: The British Broadcasting Corp. documentary, details of which were released Wednesday by its maker Edward Behr, said the U.S. prosecutors worked with the emperor&apost;s aides to find a way to avoid putting Hirohito on trial.

sentence.content: The documentary challenges Hirohito&apost;s image as a peaceful man forced to go along with his generals&apost; plans and alleges among other things that he: _Must have known about the massacre of at least 20,000 Chinese at Nanking in 1937 because he received regular detailed reports from the China front.

sentence.content: It has been reported previously that American prosecutors wanted to keep Hirohito out of the war crimes trial and asked Tojo to suggest the emperor had consented reluctantly to the war on the advice of the High Command.

sentence.content: Gen. Douglas MacArthur, commander of the U.S. forces occupying Japan, wrote in his book ``Reminiscences&apost;&apost; that he fended off pressure from Britain and the Soviet Union to indict Hirohito, arguing that would touch off a guerrilla war.
